prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for ending free friend rides in my car?
My friend always hops rides everywhere in my car. I fill up the tank and pick him up at his house and drop him back off safely at home. This past weekend he put 10 in gas because I forgot my purse home and yesterday he asked me back for it. He has ridden in my car hundreds of times without putting gas. Am I an asshole for saying find your way around in the future?
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking if the person who wrote the AITA (Am I the Asshole) post is in the wrong. The situation is about ending free friend rides in their car.

So the friend always rides with them, they fill up the gas, pick the friend up and drop him off. This past weekend, the friend put $10 in gas because the author forgot their purse at home and the friend asked for it back. The author then says "find your way around in the future," which I take to mean they're cutting off the rides. The question is whether the author is an asshole.

First, let's break down the key points. The author has been giving their friend rides regularly, covering gas costs. The friend has never contributed before but did so once when the author forgot something. Now the author is ending the rides. 

The friend's action of putting $10 in gas was probably a one-time thing, maybe to cover the cost of that particular trip since the author's purse was left home. The author's response seems to be ending the arrangement altogether. 

Is the author justified? Well, if they've always covered the gas, and the friend never contributed, it's a one-sided arrangement. The friend is taking advantage of the author's generosity. But when the friend did contribute once, the author took it as a sign to end all rides. That seems a bit harsh. Maybe the author was expecting the friend to contribute every time, but that wasn't the case before. 

The friend's one-time contribution might not be a fair reason to stop all rides. The author could have just accepted the $10 as a one-time thing and continued the rides. Alternatively, maybe the author was upset about the previous times the friend didn't contribute and used that incident as a catalyst to cut things off. 

In terms of fairness, the author is ending the rides because of a single instance where the friend contributed. That might be a bit of a disproportionate response. The friend had a valid reason to ask for the purse back, so putting $10 in gas could be seen as a good gesture, not a condition for continuing rides. 

On the other hand, the author is within their rights to set boundaries. If they're tired of covering all the costs and want to stop, it's their choice. But doing it after a one-time instance where the friend did contribute might come off as unfair. The friend might feel they're being punished for a past that wasn't their fault. 

So, is the author an asshole? If they're ending the rides because of a single act of the friend contributing when they usually didn't, it's a bit harsh. The friend's past behavior was probably the real issue, not the one time they did contribute. The author might be right to set boundaries, but the timing and reason for ending it now might be questionable. 

Therefore, the author might be in the wrong because they're ending the arrangement based on an isolated incident rather than addressing the long-standing issue of the friend not contributing. They should have communicated their expectations earlier instead of cutting things off suddenly after a single gesture.
